title: 109_hr4844
content: The "Federal Election Integrity Act of 2006" requires voters to provide photo identification. The "Federal Election Integrity Act of 2006" mandates individuals to present a government-issued photo ID when voting in person for a Federal office. The "Federal Election Integrity Act of 2006" requires individuals to show a valid government-issued photo ID, or a photo ID with proof of US citizenship for voting in Federal elections. If ID is not provided, a provisional ballot can be cast. The "Federal Election Integrity Act of 2006" mandates individuals to present a government-issued photo ID for voting in Federal elections. A provisional ballot can be cast if ID is not provided, but eligibility must be confirmed within 48 hours by presenting the required identification. The "Federal Election Integrity Act of 2006" requires individuals to provide a government-issued photo ID for voting in Federal elections, except for overseas military voters. The "Federal Election Integrity Act of 2006" mandates government-issued photo ID for voting in Federal elections, excluding overseas military voters. Absent uniformed services voters are exempt from this requirement if they are outside the US on election day. Government-issued IDs must be from the Federal Government or a State, and must show proof of US citizenship for issuance. The "Federal Election Integrity Act of 2006" requires government-issued photo ID for voting in Federal elections, with proof of US citizenship needed for ID issuance. Amendments include changing the heading of Section 303 to focus on providing photo identification and updating subsection (c) accordingly. The "Federal Election Integrity Act of 2006" mandates photo ID for voting in Federal elections starting from the 2008 general election, with requirements for providing photo identification. The "Federal Election Integrity Act of 2006" mandates photo ID for voting in Federal elections starting from the 2008 general election, with requirements for providing photo identification. States are required to establish a program to provide photo identifications for individuals who wish to vote but do not possess a government-issued photo ID, with provisions for no-cost IDs for indigent individuals. The Federal Election Integrity Act of 2006 mandates photo ID for voting in Federal elections, with states required to provide no-cost IDs for indigent individuals. The fee for a photo ID cannot exceed the reasonable cost to the state, and the ID cannot be used for other government purposes. The Federal Election Integrity Act of 2006 requires states to provide no-cost photo IDs for indigent individuals for voting in Federal elections. The Commission will make payments to cover the costs incurred by states in providing these photo identifications. The amount of payment to a state will be based on the fees that would have been collected under the program, as determined by the Commission. Authorization of appropriations is provided for these payments. Authorization of appropriations is provided for payments under the Federal Election Integrity Act of 2006 to cover costs of providing photo identifications to indigent individuals for voting in Federal elections. The amendments made by this section shall take effect on October 1, 2007.
